facts.text: Two brothers, Mahadeo and Sahdeo, members of joint Hindu family, owned certain plots of land including Nos. 170 and 74/1 in village Arazi Mafi Pandai.
Mahadeo died leaving widow Basera Kunwar, son Damodar Pande and daughter Mahura Kunwar.
Sahdeo died leaving widow Sundra Kunwar.
Ram Sewak Pande brought suit against Basera Kunwar and Sundra Kunwar for possession of zamindari property including sir and sayar left by Damodar Pande, which was dismissed.
On death of Basera Kunwar, Adit Pande (son of Ram Sewak) and Ganga Pande got names mutated in regard to the property.
Mahura Kunwar brought suit for possession of estate left by Basera Kunwar against Adit Pande and Ganga Pande, decreed on August 1, 1941.
Mahura Kunwar obtained possession through court on May 31, 1943, including plots Nos. 170 and 74/1.
Mahura Kunwar made application to Sub-Divisional Magistrate on February 25, 1950, for proceedings under s.145 CrPC against Adit Pande and Ganga Pande.
Magistrate ordered attachment of land including plots 170 and 74/1, possession given to Shubh Karan as sapurdar.
Property under attachment from March 15, 1950, to December 18, 1950, comprising part of 1357 F and 1358 F.
On December 18, 1950, s.145 proceedings ended in favour of Mahura Kunwar; possession established, Adit and Ganga restrained, attachment ended, possession handed back to Mahura Kunwar.
Adit Pande and Ganga Pande's revision to District Magistrate dismissed on March 28, 1951; actual possession delivered in April 1951.
Delivery of possession stayed from December 1950 to April 1951 under District Magistrate's order.
Appellant, Patwari of village Arazi Mafi Pandai, framed khasra of 1358 F for plots 170 and 74/1 incorrectly, entering name of Adit Pande as in possession in remarks column.
Mahura Kunwar filed complaint on July 31, 1951, under s.218 IPC against appellant in Judicial Magistrate Court, Ghazipur.
Case committed to Sessions Court, S.T. No. 11 of 1952; prosecution witnesses: Mahura Kunwar (PW1), Gouri Shankar (PW2), Naresh (PW3); defence: Adit Pande (DW1), Ram Swarup (DW2).
Sessions Judge convicted appellant under s.218 IPC on June 7, 1952, sentenced to 1 year RI and Rs.200 fine or 4 months RI default.
Allahabad High Court confirmed conviction on September 7, 1954, in Criminal Appeal No. 647 of 1952.
Appellant's plea: Learned from Shubh Karan of s.145 win, but spot possession with Adit Pande; no magistrate order received; Mahura Kunwar not in actual possession.
Shubh Karan not examined as witness; dispute between Mahura Kunwar and Shubh Karan over produce during custodianship.
Entries in khasra remarks column for 1357 F and 1358 F: 'qabiz badastur' (possession as before).
Khasra entries made in March (after s.145 decision in Dec 1950).

legal_issues.text: Whether the appellant, a Patwari and public servant, knowingly framed incorrect khasra entries for 1358 F in respect of plots 170 and 74/1 with intent to cause or knowledge likely to cause undue loss or injury to Smt. Mahura Kunwar, committing offence under s.218 IPC.

petitioner_arguments.text: Learned from Shubh Karan Chowkidar that Mahura Kunwar won s.145 case, but on spot inspection found possession with Adit Pande; did not act per magistrate order as none received; Mahura Kunwar not in actual physical possession.
Sapurdar Shubh Karan never got possession from Adit Pande; absence of Shubh Karan testimony creates doubt.

respondent_arguments.text: Appellant deliberately made wrong entries in khasra for plots 170 and 74/1, entering Adit Pande in possession despite court possession to Mahura Kunwar in April 1951; supported by PW1 Mahura, PW2 Gouri Shankar, PW3 Naresh who deposed Shubh Karan sowed crops and possession delivered.
Appellant knew of litigation between Mahura Kunwar and Adit Pande; entries incorrect to injure Mahura Kunwar.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.218 IPC; Rule 60 U.P. Land Records Manual

court_reasoning.text: Lower courts found entries incorrect knowing them so, with intent to cause gain to Adit Pande and loss to Mahura Kunwar, relying on s.145 proceedings favouring Mahura Kunwar.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Land attached and given to Shubh Karan; actual possession to Mahura Kunwar only in April 1951.

court_reasoning.text: Prosecution must prove: (1) accused knowingly framed incorrect record; (2) with intent/knowledge to cause loss/injury to public or Mahura Kunwar.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Entries incorrect, but direct evidence of intent lacking; circumstantial evidence meagre.

court_reasoning.text: No intent proved: Entries for 1358 F made in March after s.145 decision (Dec 1950); could not affect s.145 or s.16 U.P. Zamindari Abolition Act (which applies to 1356 F).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Entries could not create evidence for s.145 or benefit Adit under Zamindari Act.

court_reasoning.text: Rule 60 U.P. Land Records Manual requires entries per actual facts via inquiry and inspection by April 30.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Patwari responsible, but intent not established.

holdings.text: Prosecution failed to prove necessary criminal intention under s.218 IPC; no offence committed.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Offence of public servant framing incorrect record with intent to cause injury/loss.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Proceedings establishing possession of Mahura Kunwar; land attachment and delivery.

statutes_cited.name: U.P. Land Records Manual
statutes_cited.relevance: Requires Patwari to make khasra entries per actual facts by inquiry and inspection.

statutes_cited.name: U.P. Zamindari Abolition and Land Reforms Act, 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: Deems recorded occupant of 1356 F in possession as hereditary tenant; entries for 1358 F irrelevant.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; orders of conviction and sentence by Sessions Court and Allahabad High Court set aside; appellant acquitted of offence under s.218 IPC.

key_quotes.text: in order to sustain the conviction it is not sufficient that the entries are incorrect, it is essential that the entry should have been made with the intention mentioned in s. 218 of the Indian Penal Code.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core legal test for offence under s.218 IPC.

key_quotes.text: the prosecution has failed to prove the necessary criminal intention.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Direct evidence proving the necessary intention is, in this case, lacking and the circumstantial evidence is too meagre to support any safe conclusion as to the intention.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejection of prosecution's case on intent.
